There are even wooden and porcelain ornaments. For sure you will not find low quality products. "Kos olive tree" is an impressive new store full of natural colors and light, made with so much love and passion. A true oasis of life in the heart of the city. If you're looking for a smart and very Greek gift for you, your house or your friends, here you will surely find it.

Poi.Name: KOAKOS ELEONAS
Poi.Description:
We are a family business in Kos with a history more than 37 years in the production of olive oil, operating the first modern olive mill in Kos. In 2012 we have created our brand new olive oil bottling unit, which give us the opportunity to have the absolute control of production and bottling of our olive oil. That's how we are in position to offer high quality products to selective customers. To those who are searching for a special olive juice, reach in antioxidants and nutritional properties. Olive oil fully harmonized with the standards of the Mediterranean diet.

Our goal is not mass production, but the contribution of tasty products, enriched with antioxidants and thousands of other beneficial properties, with fruity flavor and unique aroma, capturing the aromas of the surrounding wild herbs.

The way of cultivation and harvesting, aims to the production of high quality olive oil with the lowest acidity possible and the highest nutritional value.

You are invited to visit our factory for a tour and to taste our products. Also, you can seek our products in selected local shops.
Poi.Address: 7th km on the main road Kos-Villages

Poi.Name: NANI NANI
Poi.Description:
Our thought I heard children's laughter. But where to come? Going up the road to Lampi (Volunteer Veterans), we found the answer: we were out of the store Nani - Nani and the child within us had already started laughing excited!  Stergos 2006 created a space where one can find, everything for the expectant mum and the child: types of pregnancy, baby and children up chairs and beds, through 58,000 codes and over 120 partners. We wandered in space guides the ladies Christina and Evdokia, not knowing what to spoiled, impressed with the variety, quality, price and knowledge of its people Nani - Nani. We left for the end of it, that very, very confidently told us Stergos. "The after sales service our own ... it has one"!
 Ask for the world's first "self-heated" bottle leaving request form with the check list to not miss anything of what you will need mum and baby. The phone and fax numbers Nani - Nani is 22420 25859.​

Poi.Name: LAUNDRY SERVICES
Poi.Description: ​We can fast and easy take care of all your washing and ironing  while you are working and have no time or spend your vacation in our beautiful island.We are in Kos center, 200 meters from the marina and in two hours you can have your dirty clothes clean and smelling like Mom's!​

Poi.Name: Orea Ellas
Poi.Description: ​The only shop in the traditional village Lagoudi on the mountain of Dikeos, 15 km from Kos town and 2,5 km from the famous for its sunsets village of Zia. The paintres Christina Colman lives and works here and has created her own paradise. An art gallery with icons and paintings made by her, old objects, furniture and jewellery scattered in the wonderful garden with lemon trees, pomegranate trees, lotus trees and avogado trees. On the highest point of the garden is a magical, traditional cafe, where you can enjoy homemade lemonade with an unique view over the sea to the island of Pserimos and the turkish coastline. Chistina will tell you stories from the 28 years that she is living in Lagoudi after moving here from Antwerp, Belgium. The place captured immediately her hart as it will capture yours. Open all year, from 11.00 a.m. untill after midnight.

Poi.Name: Roman Odeon of Kos
Poi.Description:
The Roman Auditorium is thought to have been one of the most crucial public buildings of ancient Kos. It was found by the Italian archeologist Laurenzi in an excavation conducted in 1929.
 
Erected during the 2nd century A.D it is believed to have taken the place of an older public building that could have been the parliament of the city.

Despite the auditorium being originally designed for hosting musical competitions, it was also used as the seat for the local senate.

The building was initially roofed and seated approximately 750 persons. Its cavea with a northern orientation was supported by arched constructions built on pillars of caster masonry (opus caementicium). It had fourteen rows of marble seats, nineteen of which have been restored, and was divided by a corridor into two sections; the cunei of the lower section were divided by four staircases. Under the cavea lied two semicircular porticos and a series of rooms used as shops or workrooms.
 
The form of the scene was unusual: an irregular pentagon made of two parts, the proscenium (front of scene) and the paraskenio (backstage), communicating thanks to three entrances. On both sides of the scene were two more doors leading to the parodoi (passageways). The floor of the circular orchestra was decorated with opus sectile (marble works), while mosaic floorings adorned the parodoi.
 
The inner galleries of the Odeon were decorated with marble statues initially standing in niches; the most notable is that of Hippokrates, today exhibited at the Archaeological Museum of Kos.

Today the auditorium hosts a number of cultural happenings. Moreover, within the Auditorium the exhibition of photography of the Aegean Institute of archeological studies is housed.

Poi.Name: Casa Romana - Roman Villa
Poi.Description:
The "Casa Romana", or the Roman Manor is one of the most interesting sites on the island of Kos.

In 1933 the great earthquake nearly destroyed the whole island. The Italians, who at the time of the earthquake were occupying the island, perceived the destruction as an opportunity to reconstruct the city's building plan, conducting numerous excavations, with the knowledge that beneath the leveled structures ancient monuments lay.

Laurenzi, the head archeologist was in charge of the excavation, with the Italian administration of the island conducting a full restoration project that lasted until 1940.
The site is a Roman Manor of the Pompei model, erected between the late 2nd and the early 3rd century A.D. Built on the ruins of an earlier Hellenistic house, with an excellent drainage system, the manor comprises 36 rooms and three atriums.

Its exterior view of the site does not prepare the visitor for what lies within. Walking through the main entrance one only begins to grasp the manor's beauty. There one encounters a statue's base bearing the inscription “ΑΠΕΛΕΞΙΚΑΚΟΣ” (he who repels evil). In the first atrium a small reservoir and a mosaic portraying a panther devouring a deer, of pristine quality, may be found. Nearly every room of the manor features stunning mosaics and beautiful decors. The manor's central room ("ανδρώνας") exhibits signs of orthomarmarosis and bear mosaic floors of geometric ornaments, depictions of tigers panthers and others. The auxiliary rooms are to be found in the northwest side near the stairs leading to the first floor. In every atrium one may find reservoirs of various sizes and mosaics of mythological and physical subjects such as the Niriyds or dolphins. Within the structure statues of nymphs, of Athena and a mosaic depicting the ocean bed can be viewed.

Poi.Name: Church of St. John the Baptist
Poi.Description:
​The church of Saint John the Baptist is an early Christian Baptistery built in the 5th or 6th century AD. The temple is located inside the cemetery of the city and today it functions as the cemetery church of the city of Kos. It is perhaps the only early Christian Baptistery surviving to this day.

The building was surrounded by wide, vaulted corridors, from which only the foundations remain today. On the outside it is shaped as a rectangle, while on the insied it has a circular shape, with four alcoves in its four corners and one in the middle of its eastern side. However its walls form 8 dents, together with one to the west, 7 of which resemble altars (Bemas) of the eastern orthodox churches. This is why the temple is known as the "Seven Bemas" church.

Recently in the temple frescoes dated to the 12th or 13th century have been uncovered, portraying scenes from the life of the Saint.

Poi.Name: The Castle of Antimachia
Poi.Description:
​The castle of Antimachia is located in the center of the island of Kos, southeast of the village of Antimachia. It is a remarkable medieval fortress. According to written testaments of the 14th century, the castle also served as a prison for condemmned knights.

The castle is build along a hill with a view to the southern coast of Kos. It has a triangular shape with a peak to the east. Every side of the castle is organized as an independent fortification line that follows the shape of the terrain.

At the entrance there is a massive crescent shaped bastion  with deep ramparts. The castle was renovated by the Knights Templar in 1494 after a destructive earthquake. The existing walls were reinforced and new battlements of various types were added along the external wall.

Inside the castle, one still finds ruins of the old settlement of Antimachia, many cisterns and two churches. The settlement was abondened in 1840.

Poi.Name: Castle and Old Town of Pyli
Poi.Description:
The ruins of the old town of Pyli and its castle can be found on a hilltop, 3-4 kilometers away from the modern village of Pyli, approximately 17 kilometers from the city of Kos.

The old town is an abandoned settlement on the foot of a Byzantine castle, built in the times of Macedonian dynasty (9th century A.D. - 11th century A.D.). When the knights of Saint john took hold of the island in the 14th century, they enforced the fortifications on the casstle in order to improve the area's defensive capacities.

From the castle the visitor will enjoy magnifficent views of the nearby islands of Pserimos and Kalymnos and of the shores of Asia Minor.

The old town itself has been called "the Mystras of the Dodekanese", implying the importance of its medieval archaeological monuments such as its byzantine churches. Of particular importance is the 14th century church of Ypapanti (Candlemas), with its beautiful frescoes, a wonderful wood carved altar piece and columns from an older temple of the vicinity. Another church worth visiting is the temple of the Archangels (church of the Taxiarche). 

It should also be noted that that the founder of the monastery of Patmos saint Christodoulos originally founded a monastery here in Pyli, the monastery of the Castriani, the Catholicon of which is still preserved today as the Flevariotisa church.

Poi.Name: Agios Nikolaos
Poi.Description:
The unparalleled magnificence of the church of Saint Nicholas made the temple the pride of the islanders. Its construction begun in 1857 and was finished by 1862.The significance of the monument to the people of the time is testified by the multiple private plots of land sold to meet its outrageous cost of 40.00 kurus. The temple stood for the greater part of 70 years until the earthquake of the 23rd of April 1933 which caused irreversible damage necessitating its demolition in 1934.

The demolition work was entrusted to the Italian firm of "Sardeli"> Their efforts were concentrated on the consvervation of the marble altarpiece, the marble Episcopal throne and the marble tiles.

The painstaking work was supervised by the mechanic Coccheri and his partners. Coccheri is said in fact to have been miraculously saved from an 8 meter fall from the temples ceiling. The accident was interpreted by the townspeople as a portent, signifying the self sacrifice demanded for the completion of the work, earning Cocherri a golden cross granted to him by Arch bishop Philimonas. In the meantime by the end of 1935 the Italians declared Saint Nicholas, patron of the island erecting his statue over a cranny, siting upon two arches, overlooking Miaoulis beach.

After the demolition, the Italian tetrarch, governor of the Dodecanese Cesare Maria De Vechi denied every request of the islanders to be granted permission for the reconstruction, but was persuaded otherwise when a cyclone hit and destroyed the Italian hydroplanes in the sea within the temple's vicinity, believing the phenomenon to be the manifestation of divine will. The new church of Saint Nicholas was rebuilt between 1937 and 1939. The expenditure for the reconstruction reached 350.000 aigrettes and such the temple was rebuilt from its roots.

Kos celebrates its patron Saint with the utmost religious respect and festive spirit on the 6th of December. The celebration is marked by the great evening mass lead by the archbishop of Kos and Nisyros. The liturgy is carried out by priests of the city and is attended by represntatives of the army, the navy, the state and local authorities.

Poi.Name: The cave of White Stone
Poi.Description:
Dated between 140-100 million years ago the cave of aspri petra can be found atop mount Zini in Kefalos, at an altitude of 257 meters, in the southwestern part of the island. The area was excavated by Alessandro Della Seta, director of the Italian archeological school of Athens and the archeologist Doro Levi in 1922. The cave is composed of layers of solid and dry rock which enabled its continuous use, initially as a place of residence and later as a place of worship.

Human fossils and multiple ceramic urns of bowlike-sagittal handles decorated with varying figures and of various sizes were prominent among the findings, with weaponry being very rare. Few blades and sharp cores made of obsidian, from Yali, an Island near Nisiros. The remnants of the nutriments speak of a people dedicated to pastoral life. Of note was the presence of holes filled with egg shaped milestones.

The cave is one of the oldest monuments of the island.

Poi.Name: Temple of Hercules
Poi.Description:
Located near the Plane Tree of Hippocrates, this temple, deidcated to Hercules, is dated to the 2nd century B.C. It is built upon a trapezoid shaped mound. Upon the northernmost corner of the mound stood a rectangular temple. From this temple, the only surviving parts are the Efthentiria (part of the foundation of the temple), the Crepidoma (the platform on which the superstructure of the building was erected) and the Orthostate (stone blocks built into the lower portion of the wall). 
 
The temple is considered to have been dedicated to Hercules, due to an inscription and objects associated with Hercules found on the site as well as findings related to the legend of this hero.

According to historical sources after the demolition of the surrounding area between the second and third centuries A.D, a columnade was erected and decorated with mosaics. One of these mosaics depicted the "Symposium of Hercules". In the same area one may encounter buildings belonging to later eras, such as a baptistery and a small bathhouse.

Poi.Name: Temple of Apollo in Kardamena
Poi.Description:
The temple of Apollo in Kardamena (in antiquity known as Alasarna) , was in its time one of most impressive Hellenistic monuments in Kos.Its foundations have been uncovered underneath a building of the early Christian period. This discovery has strongly supported that life in the settlement of Alasarna goes well beyond the times of late antiquity. Alasarna along with the Asklepieion remained a religious center even after the founding of new Kos in 336 B.C.
 
Unfortunately,  a large part of the temple was destroyed during the construction of a local hotel. In the sanctuary three distinct buildings have so far been excavated: Building A was excavated in 1981 and includes the well known, through inscriptions, sanctum of Apollo. Building B could either be an altar or an inclined entrance to the temple. Building C, although note precicely dated yet, is most probably a temple dated between late classical and early Hellenistic times.

The temple was discovered during a salvage excavation that was conducted by C.Kantzia in 1985. Excavations are carried on today by a team of professors from the University of Athens in cooperation with volunteer student groups.

Poi.Name: The sanctuary of Asclepios (Asclepieion)
Poi.Description:
The Asclepieion of Kos is built upon the slopes of hill clothed in lush flora and graced with beautiful views of the sea and the Turkish coast. It is the most important monument of the island and of the most important temples of its kind of antiquity. In the ancient times it was the place of worship of the god Asclepius, healing grounds for the ill and a school for the study of medicine. Hippocrates, one of the greatest exemplars of the medical profession taught in the school that he instituted within the sanctuary's area . In contrast to the more arcane sanctum of Asclepius in Epidaurus, its counterpart in Kos Island cultivated scientific medicine.

The Asclepieion of Kos, whose surviving ruins are dated to the 4th century B.C, is located 3.4 kilometers northwest of the city. The three successive terraces are dated to the Hellenistic years; their specific oriental style was probably adopted after Alexander’s conquests.

During the reign of the Ptolemys’ in 260 B.C a critical event marked the history of the monument. The Asclepieion was recognized as a Pan-Hellenic asylum for the preparation of the celebration of the Asclepieia. The pursuit of the islanders to offer asylum to those prosecuted, is a clear sign of how proud they were for their temple which they considered to be the center of their city.

The discovery of the Asclepieion took place in 1902 by the German archeologist Rudolf Herzog and the local history buff, Iakovos Zaraftis. The search for the site was strongly motivated by the  fourth mime of Herondas “Women with dedications and sacrifices to the Asclepieion” in which he speaks with apparent admiration to Kos and describes images and statues from the temple. The excavations were carried on by Laurenzi (1930) and Morricone (1937-38) along with restoration works. It should be noted that many objects from the digs were poached away to Rome and Constantinople.

Poi.Name: Archaeological Museum of Kos
Poi.Description:
​The two storey bulding on Eleftherias Square that houses the Archaeological museum of Kos is a protected monument of the Italian occupation era (1912 - 1943), built in 1935.

It is considered a sample of the international style bequeathed by the Italian occupation to the atrchitectural history of Kos, although some view this as a sample of italian fascist monument architecture.

The museum boasts a rich collection of artifacts from antiquity, up until the late Roman era.

The most important sculptures and mosaics are on display in the ground floor and in the atrium of the museum. The western hall exhibits statues of the hellenistic era, most of which were found stored in the arcades of the Odeon.

The northern hall hosts the imposing statue of Hippocrates (4th century B.C.), a late Roman era wall mounted relief portraying a symposium, as well as funerary sculptures of the late archaic and classical eras.

Statues of Demetra, Kore and Athena dated from the mid 4th to the mid 3rd centuries B.C. can be found in the Northern hall of the museum. The Eastern hall exhibits statues of the Roman era, including a sitting Hermes and a statue of Demetra.

Finally, one more mosaic of the Hellenistic era from the excavation of the now restored Casa Romana, portraying the bottom of the sea adorns the northern wall of the peristyle.

Poi.Name: Ancient Agora Ko
Poi.Description:
​In antiquity, the agora (forum) of every city was its commercial and social centre. The ancient Agora of Kos is among the largest to have been excavated in Greece to this date. Originally it was built during the 4th century B.C.  near the city's port.

After 366 B.C. when the city of Kos was recognized as an important administrative center, important public and religious buildings were constructed in the area of the port and of the Agora. The latter was the financial heart of the island, with streets, workshops, shops and altars that consitute the "traditional" image of an ancient agora.

The archaeological site was excavated by the Italian Archaeological School, during the reconstruction of the city, after the destructive earthquake of 1933. The Agora had trhee main gates (eastern, western, northern). The roads from the three gates convergedin the center in a large internal courtyard. The northern gate connected the Agora with the city walls, while the other two hosted a number of shops tending to the citizens' everyday needs.

The frequent earthquakes hitting the island were a reason for repeated reconstructions of the city. Different materials used by the locals help distinguis the diferent construction phases.

The earthquake of the 6th or 5th century B.C. left no traces to the construction history of the city. From 366 B.C. and all through the third century, buildigns are created with "amygdalopetra", a type of limestone and greenish poros stone. Marble is rare.

During the next period, marble is used widely. During the 2nd century B.C. the monumental buildings are constructing, giving a magnificent view to the city.

The reconstruction that followed the earthquake of 142 A.D. changed the image of the city once again. New construction methods are used ("cast wall making") and new buildings and complexes are constructed, such as the Thermes, the theater and the stadium. The agora and the neighboring building blocks are reconstructed.

The earthquake of 469 A.D. brought a critical change that marked the end of the ancient city and the beginning of the early christian era.

Today, the ruins of the Agora are part of the broader archaeological zone of the port, which covers an area of 152 meters long by 82 meters wide. The visitor can see among others the Agora, part of the fortication of the city, the sanctuaries of Aphrodite and Hercules, building blocks with some remains of private houses but also a part of the ancient port of the city. However the biggest part of the Agora lies burried under the modern city. The southern part of the Agora was only recently excavated - opposite the altar of Dionysus.

Panoramic Photo


Kos Ancient Market in Greece

Poi.Name: Folk Museum of Antimachia
Poi.Description:
​The folk museum in Antimachia is located in the village square close to the traditional mill. 

The museum, also known as the "Stone House of Antimachia" is housed in an old stone building, a typical specimen of twentieth century rural architecture in Kos. Its exhibits include various tools, traditional furniture and old appliances. It contains a room with looms and a room for making and baking bread. Outside the house there is a hencoop and a pig pen.

Poi.Name: Aliki Tigaki (Salt Lake)
Poi.Description:
Between the villages of Tigaki and Marmari on the northern coast of the island lies the protected area of the Aliki (Salt Lake). The area functioned as a salt production installation until 1989.

The lagoon is filled with fresh water from two torrents as well as with sea water through a duct. During the last years, the entrance of sea water during the summer months has resulted in the retention of water throughout the year. The area is protected under the Ramsar and Natura conventions and hosts a variety of flora and fauna, including migratory birds, such as pelicans and flamingos as well as aquatic animals such as water turtles and water snakes.

Poi.Name: The wetland of Psalidi
Poi.Description:
The Psalidi wetland is a brakish marsh created by two torrents flowing into the coastline of Psalidi. The marsh is connected to the sea through a natural water duct created by dirt and reeds. Water is retented in the marsh throughout the year.

Fairly close to the city (4 kilometers eastwards) its covers an area of approximately 85-100 hectares. During the Italian occupation, the wetland was used as a salt lake for the production of salt. Today among the rich fauna of the wetland one may find water-turtles flamingos and herons. The swamp is a wild life reservoir under the protection of the Greek state and the Natura convention (SPA-GR4210027).

Poi.Name: Fortress of Neratzia Bridge
Poi.Description:
​The bridge of the Castle of Neratzia that connects the Plain Tree Square with the enstrance to the Castle. The castle pf Neratzia on the seafront of the city of Kos was built duiring the Knighthood period of the island. A bridge used to connect the inner with the outer yard of the castle, over the ditch that connected the sea of the port with the eastern sea side of the castle. This bridge has survived to this dat and today it connects the square of the Plain Tree with the entrance to the Castle, over the picturesque Palm tree boulevard.

Panoramic Photo


Kos-island-Κως in Greece

Poi.Name: Plaka
Poi.Description:
The pine forest of Plaka is located near the village of Antimachia. The forest is home to a large number of tame, free roaming peackocks; visitors may touch and feed them since they are familiar and friendly to people.
 
Its location within a gorge and the dense shade of the trees create a cool and rejuvinating atmosphere, even in the hot summer days. Visitors can admire the peackocks, enjoy their stroll and relax on the benches that are situated in parts of the forest.

Poi.Name: Panagia Tsoukalaria
Poi.Description: On the verge of the suburban forest of Kos, on the way towards Ambavri, lies the church of Panagia ​Tsoukalaria. Around the church there is free space for recreation and rest. Next to the church one may see parts of the ancient water supply system of Kos, starting from the Vourina springs.

Poi.Name: Jewish Synagogue
Poi.Description:
In the center of the city, very close to the port lies the Jewish Synagogue and, next ot it, the Rabbi's residence. The temple functions today as a municipal cultural center.

The temple is a witness for the continuous presence of a Jewish community in Kos that goes back all the way to the second century B.C. Expelled in the 14th century by the Knights Templar, the jews returned to Kos two centuries later after the Ottoman conquest. The community was totally annihilated in 1945 when all its members were transferred to the Auschwitz concetration camp, with only one member managing to return to Kos.

The building of the Synagogue replaced an older Synagogue building which was destroyed during the earthquake of 1933.

Poi.Name: Hani
Poi.Description: In the southern part of the city of Kos, amidst archaelogical sites and monuments lies the Hani building. Originally used as a building catering for the animals of ​travellers, today the Hani hosts an exhibition of the modern history of Kos and of the Italian era architecture that characterises many of the buildings in Kos.

Poi.Name: The Tomb of Harmylos
Poi.Description: The ancient tomb of King Harmylos, ruler of the island, is one of the most curious and interesting archeological monuments of Kos. Located in the neighborhood Harmyli of the village Pyli , aptly named after the monument, the site is located 300 hundred meters away from the main square. It consists of a semicircular building containing 12 crypts ordered in parallel lines of 6, built within the walls. The tomb is dated approximately to the 3rd century B.C. It served as an heroon (temple dedicated to a hero) in its time. In olden times the façade of the building was covered by an ionic gallery chiseled in white marble. The said marble tiles along with the inscription which confesses to the date of the monument were removed from their original places and can now be found mounted onto the walls of the church of Stavros, above the tomb itself.

Poi.Name: Traditional Mill in Antimachia
Poi.Description: ​This traditional flourmill is located on the main square of the village of Antimachia, close to the airport of Kos, approximately 22 kilometers from the town of Kos. On the same square, one can visit the exhibition of the traditional house of Antimachia, the local folk museum.

Poi.Name: Tigaki Square
Poi.Description: ​This square is located in the center of the Tigaki resort, a village on the northern coast of the island, 14 kilometers from the city of Kos. To reach the square one can use the northern country road, driving by beautiful beaches.

Poi.Name: Asomatos Square
Poi.Description: ​The traditional village of Asomatos with the homonymous church of Ag. Asomaton is located on the eastern side of the Dikaios mountain, in a short distance from the village of Zia. The five neighboring villages of Zia, Asomatos, Lagoudiou, Haihouton and Evagelistrias are traditional villages built in a particularly beautiful forested area, rich in fresh water springs and just 14 kilometers from the city of Kos.

Poi.Name: Platani Square
Poi.Description: In the southwester corner of the city of Kos, in the center of the Platani suburb, this square hosts some of the best known traditional restaurants in Kos, serving meals prepared from local produce. ​

Poi.Name: St. Nicholaus Square - Pyli Water Spring
Poi.Description: The water spring of Pyli is located in the center of the Pyli village, next to the St. Nicholaus church. Fresh, drinking water gushes from six spouts on the sides of a square building with a flat roof. As mentioned in the embedded inscription on the south side of the bulding, the spring was renovated in 1592. For centuries it has been used to provide water to the locals and to irrigate the orchards in the area. Today, the spring is one of the most central spots of Pyli and a meeting place for the locals.

Poi.Name: Linopoti Lake
Poi.Description:
​The lake of Pyli, or "Neromana" (sic mother of water) is a small artificial fresh water lake created by a periferal damm in an area with karstic springs. In the olden days, this lake irrigated the whole plain of Pyli.

The lake is located 1,5 kilometers northeast of the city of Kos. Its surface covers an area of approximately 2000 - 3000 square meters. The lake was created under orders of the Italian occupation forces in order to help fight against the water shortages that plaiged the area. Before that, according to historical testimony, the area was a vast medow, frequently turning into a marsh and very difficult to cross with the means available in those times.

Today the lake is home to a variety of flora and fauna. The visitor may see animals such as water turtles, ducks, eals and mosquitofish. The lake is surrounded by fresh-water canes, aspen trees and oleander. Many visitors stop by the lake to take pictures and feed some of the animals.

Poi.Name: Kefalos Port
Poi.Description:
In the beautiful bay of Kefalos, on the western ​part of Kos at a distance of 40 kilometers from the city of Kos lies the port of Kefalos. The port acts mostly as a shelter for local fishing vessels. The area with its crystal clear blue waters host many traditional fish restaurants and tavernas.

Panoramic Photo


Kamari harbour in Greece

Poi.Name: Therma
Poi.Description:
Therma are located in the southeastern part of the island, about 13km from the town of Kos.

The landscape has a wild beauty, steep slopes, cliffs and dark pebbles; result of tectonic disturbances and volcanic eruptions millions of years ago.

The area takes its name from the hot springs that gush water into the sea. This hot spring water is rich in calcium, potassium, sodium, sulfur and magnesium; substances considered  to aid the healing of skin, arthritic and rheumatic diseases and also improve the general condition the skin. The temperature of the water ranges from 30 to 50 degrees Celsius. The experience is invaluable, a natural Spa!

In front of the beach has been created a small lake that is separated from the rest of the beach with rocks that allow seawater to enter and cool the hot water. The beach is suitable for all ages and for all seasons.

You can visit Therma either by bus or by any private means of transportation.

Poi.Name: Kos Port
Poi.Description:
At the center of the city of Kos, on its northern coast lies the natural harbour of Kos, that hosts the Port of Kos. The port is used by both tourist vessels as well as ferries making routes towards the mainland as well as other islands.

In this same harbour lie the remains of the ancient port of Kos. The surrounding area was rebuilt by the Italians after the desctructive earthquake of 1933.

Panoramic Photo


Kos harbour in Greece

Poi.Name: Kardamena Port
Poi.Description: Next to the main square of Kardamena, on the northern coast of the island, 26 kilometers from the city of Kos lies the port of Kardamena. The port is used for local routes to Nisyros and Tilos. In this port there is also space for a limited number of tourist vessels.

Poi.Name: Mastihari Port
Poi.Description: Mastichari, on the northern coast of Kos is a pitcuresque seaside village with a small port. The port of Mastichari services local passenger routes to other islands in the Dodekanese​.

Poi.Name: Zipari Square
Poi.Description: ​The Zipari Square is in the center of the newly built settlement of Zipari, on the main road that connects Kos Town with Kefalos, approximately 11 kilometers from the city of Kos.

Poi.Name: Kefalos Square
Poi.Description: The traditionali village of Kefalos, with its small square, is located on the westernmost corner of the island, about 43 kilometers from the city of Kos. The village is built close to what many perceive as the ancient capital of Kos, Astypalaia. The square is very close to the medieval castle of Kefalos.​

Poi.Name: Kardamena Square
Poi.Description: The square of Kardamena is located in the center of the homonymous village, on the southern coast of the island, 26 kilometers from the city of Kos. In the past, Kardamena was a picturesque fishing village. Today Kardamena is one of the most developed touristically areas of Kos, visited by thousands of tourists who seek serenity and relaxation in the more than 6.000 meters long bea​ches of Kardamena.

Poi.Name: Pyli Square
Poi.Description: ​The square, loacated next to the church of Saint Nicolaus has always been the center of this agricultural village, hosting shops, restaurants and traditional cafes. Next to the square the visitor will come accross the Pyli spring.

Poi.Name: Konitsis Square
Poi.Description: ​This square is located in the center of Kos and is surrounded by Italian architecture buildings. Konitsis Square is perhaps the shopping center of Kos, since many of the city's shops lie within a short distance of the square. If you are planning a shopping trip in the city, then this is perhaps the best starting point.

Poi.Name: Eleytherias Square
Poi.Description:
​Eleftherias square (square of Freedom) is the center of the city of Kos. The square acuired it's current structure and arrangement after the great earthquake of 1933, when many of the neighboring buildings were rebuilt. From this spot a visitor has quick and easy access to most sites and monuments of the Hellenistic, Roman, Byzantine, Knighthood, Ottoman and Italian eras of the city.

Besides its historical importance and beauty, the square is a point of reference for many locas and foreigners, since on its northern side lies the port, on its eastern side the start of the old town of Kos and on its eastern side the well known bar street.

Poi.Name: Tree of Hippocrates
Poi.Description:
Opposite the fortress of Neratzia, next to the ancient Αgora of Kos, one of the most ancient trees of Kos lays its roots: the plane tree of Hippocrates, a historical site visited by thousands every year.

According to tradition the plane tree was planted by Hippocrates 24 centuries ago. Under its shadow the great teacher instructed his students. The tree's perimeter reaches 12 meters and its hollow trunk is reminiscent of a cave. The surrounding area is a stone paved square leading to the castle's bridge. Two springs from the Ottoman times lie near the tree bearing an Arabic inscription that informs the passer by that their water is the water of Hippocrates.

The tree belongs to the species platanus orientalis L .and its age is thought to surpass 2.300 years. The diameter of the trunk is 4.7 meters wide at its base, and its perimeter stretches to 12 meters. The passage of time has left the trunk and some old branches rotten, under the influence of various fungi and wood eating moths leading to the presence of the said large hollow.
 


Virtual Tour




Kos - Hippocrates Platan square in Greece

Poi.Name: Altar of Dionysos
Poi.Description:
The altar of Dionysus is located at Gregoriou the 5th street, quite close to the "Casa Romana" monument, on the same level with the Hellenistic Agora, approximately 3 meters below the level of the modern city.
 
It consitutes a typical example of a Hellenistic period altar of. The surviving part of the structure dates to the 2nd century BC, a time of prosperity for the city. It is assumed that the construction of the altar was sponsored by the king of Pergamon, in Asia Minor. 
 
During the Byzantine period, the altar was abandoned and when the Knights conquered the island, they used several architectural parts of the building, such as cornerstones with bas reliefs on one or two sides for the building of the castle. These conrerstones were removed from the castle in 1958.
 
The frieze of the Altar depicts scenes from the Amazons as well as a group of Dionysean maenads, satyrs and silen. The frieze is preserved in a designated area within the castle.
 
The archaeological site of the altar of Dionysus also includes a Doric temple antis, probably dedicated to Dionysus and two rectangular structures one of which is considered to be a pedestal for a statue and the second either another pedestal or an older altar.

 

From the ancient altar, what remains today and can be seen by the visitor is a rectangular wall, which is actually the upper part of the temple's foundation, the entrance to the altar and part of a stone wall inside the altar.

Poi.Name: Lozia Mosque
Poi.Description:
​The Gazi Hasan Pasa Mosque, better known as the Lozia Mosque or the Plane  Tree Mosque is located on the Lozia Square, near the tree of Hippocrates. On the water spout near the tree, an inscription in arabic informs the visitor that the water spout and the mosque were built by Gazi Hasa Pasha, the Capudan Pasha (Admiral) of the islands in 1786.

A tradition saved by Zarraftis claims that the mosque was previously a Christian temple dedicated to Saint George. With the mosqu being just a few meters away from the basilica, it is possible that the early Christian monument which was built in its place was dedicated to this saint.

Marbles and stones used in the construction originated from ancient buildings; mostly from the ruins of the Christian Basilika on the port and from the Baptistery of Saint John, also called "Seven Steps".

Poi.Name: Kos Mosque
Poi.Description: The Defterdar mosque, located on Eleftherias Square, in the center of Kos is named after the Ottoman Sultan's finance minister, Ibrahim Efendi, who built the mosque in 1780.​

Poi.Name: Agios Stefanos
Poi.Description: 42 kilometers from the city of Kos, near the village of Kardamena and right on the Kamari beach, facing the small island of Kastraki, lie the remains of two early christian basilicas of Saint Stefanos. The temples are dated to 469 A.D. and 554 A.D. They were discovered by the Italian archaeologist, Luciano Laurenzi and they consitute a signifficant sight due to their exceptional location, their size and their rich mosaics preserved to this day.

Poi.Name: Marina Kos
Poi.Description:
​The Marina of Kos is the most popular mooring point on the island. Is also a very welcoming place for a stroll. Visitors admire the small and larger tourist vessels that moor in the Marina during the summer months.

The Marina also hosts a cafe and a restaurant, both with wonderful views to the sea.

Poi.Name: Kos Cathedral
Poi.Description:
The Church of Evangelismos was constructed in 1930 as a Catholic church. In the same complex there is the church library, the theater and lecture hall with capacity of 150 people and the residence of the Bishop. The church has collected and exhibits a number of old remarkable Byzantine icons.

.The Metropolis of Kos is located in a prominent location near the sea and a short distance from the center of Kos and stays open during the morning hours

Poi.Name: Castle of Neratzia
Poi.Description:
​The castle of Kos, better known as the castle of Nerantzia (castle of the sour orange tree), is the most important part of the fortifications constructed on the island by the Knights Templar at the end of the 14th century A.D. It ows its name to the many sour orange trees that were planted in Kos during the late years of the 14th century and the early years of the 15th century, when the whole city came to be called by this name.

The castle consists of two fortified curtain walls. The inner curtain wall is the oldest. It is rectangular shaped and on its corners boasts 4 high towers. A wide moat (ditch) seperates the two curtain walls which are connected only by a single inclined road on the eastern side of the castle.

The castle of Nerantzia along with the castle of Saint Peter on the opposite coast of Ancient Alicarnasus (today's Bodrum Castle) controlled the sea way towards the holly lands during the period of the crusades.

In the construction of the castle various architectural elements from the ancient city of Kos and the Asclepieion were used. Many of these can still be seen today embedded in the walls of the castle.

During the 19th century the castle was used as the barracks of the Turkish garrisson and as the home of the Turkish commander of the island.
 
On March 17th 1816 a gun poweder room exploded by accident and destroyed a large part of castle. The castle's current state is a result of the restoration efforts of the Italian Arcaheological Department, which, during the Italian occupation period, removed the additions that had been created during the Ottoman era and tried to restore the castle to its original state and form.
 
During the German occupation, the castle hosted the German garrison and was used as a prison for the emprisonment of Greek patriots.

Poi.Name: Castle of Kefalos
Poi.Description:
As one enters the village of Kefalos, one can see the remains of the local Castle. The castle was built of small stones and inside it contained many water reservoirs.

The Kefalos castle is dated back to the Byzantine era. The oldest reference to the castle is dated to 1271. In 1457 tha castle was used in a successful attempt to defend the island from a Turkish invasion. In 1493 and after a destructive earthquake, the castle was almost totally destroyed. As a result, by 1505 the castle had been abandoned.

Today from the deserted ruins, the visitor can enjoy great panoramic views of the bay of Kefalos.

Poi.Name: Mount Dikaios
Poi.Description:
Mount Dikaios, also known since antiquity as Oromedon, Orion or Dikaion, is the highest mountain of Kos with an altitude of 846 meters above sea level. The origin of its name remains a mystery. Its range is mainly composed of limestone, marble, plutonites and volcanites. Right on the connecting point of the volcanites with limestone and marble various, metal stores are formed with oxidized multicolor metals being fairly common.

The mountain range is quite asymmetrical in terms of its distribution of altitudes. In the south, within a 2 kilometer radius the mountain is heavily inclined towards the sea. On the other hand, to the north the distance between the range and the shore varies between 6-7 kilometers. The very shape of the island is determined by the axis of its fissures and creases, while all torrents of the island are vertically oriented towards it. The ruins of a medieval settlement some water tanks clay fragments and some carved stones betray an ever-present human intrusion. The views from the chapel of our lord Christ at the range's peak as well as from other overlooks found within the mountains are quite breathtaking.

Poi.Name: Ancient Stadium of Kos
Poi.Description:
​On the junction of 31st of May street and Great Alexander street lie the ruins of the ancient stadium of Kos. The stadium located opposite the church of St. Ann (south west of the ruins of the north Thermes) is dated to the first half of the 2nd century B.C. It was discovered in part by Herzog who first excavated the remains of seven columns and in part by Laurenzi, who uncovered later seats made of travertine distributed in various semi circular linings. This discovery confirmed the hypothesis that the newly found ruins were those of the stadium. During Morricone’s excavation of 1939-1940 no seats were found in their original positions, however the archaeologists uncovered great plaques made of blue black marble, upon which the columns were fixed.
 
The length of track did not surpass an average of 180 meters while was approximately 30 meters. The architecture of the stadium, combines Doric and Ionic elements. 

Laurenzo uncovered architectural parts of Doric style, fragments of columns, architraves and column heads made of white marble.

An interesting inscription found in the perimeter of the stadium near St Ann’s church referring to a certain {He}rylo who as a paidonomos looked after the health and the good behavior of the youths. The inscription was dedicated to Alseios Zeus and Alseia Athena and stood on the pedestal of a votive statue:

 {Χαι}ρύλος Νικομάχου νεώ(τερος) {παιδο}νομών υπέρ τας των {παίδων} υγείας και ευταξίας {Διί Αλσεί}ωι και Αθάνα Αλσεία
Poi.Address: 31st of May street & Great Alexander street

Poi.Name: Saint Paraskevi
Poi.Description: The church of Saint Paraskevi is located at the center of the city of Kos and was constructed in the early 1930s. It is one of the largest churches of Kos and daily remains open during the morning hours and during the hours of the Divine Liturgy.

Poi.Name: Church of St Ioannes Naukleros
Poi.Description:
The church dates from the early 15th century and was originally dedicated to St John the Baptist, patron and protector of the Knights of St John. The main theme that occupies the church, such us the representation of an Apocalyptic Vision in the conch of the apse, perhaps is associated with the prevailing beliefs in Christendom in this critical period, on the coming of the end of the world.

It was in a ruined state before 1861, when, the Community of Kos decided to undertake its conservation. After the earthquake of 1933, it was found that the church was built upon the important twin sanctuary of Aphrodite. So for the sanctuary to be revealed, it was decided in 1943 to relocate it in a northwest part of the area.

In 1947 the church was dedicated by the Metropolitan of Kos, Emmanuel Karpathiou, to a Koan Neomartyr, St Ioannes Naukleros.

Poi.Name: Church of St George Arrenagogeioy
Poi.Description:
The temple is located near the limits of the walled Hospitallier city, close to Ancient Agora of Kos and it is dated since the late Byzantine period. The altar table in the bema consists of an inscribed marble plaque and a rectangular marble altar. Next to the church is the tomb of Archbishop Gerasimos of Kos (1838) and his mother Anthoula.
According to the Metropolis of Kos in the late 18th century St. George was a dependency (metochion) of the church of Agia Marina and stood in a fenced vineyard with farm-building. Later, when Arrenagogeion (Elementary School for Boys) was established, the church was included in the school yard and took the prosonym Saint George toy Arrenagogeioy.
After the earthquake of 1933, while the Boys' school was destroyed, the church of St. George was one of the few buildings that survived.

Poi.Name: Womens monastery of Agios Nektarios
Poi.Description: ​Womens monastery of Agios Nektarios.

Poi.Name: Western Archaeological Zone
Poi.Description:
The western archaeological zone is located opposite the ancient theater and is part of the town that was abandoned in the Middle Ages and throughout the period of Hospitaller, and, when it was later excavated, it revealed some of the most important structures of Kos. The monuments found there are:

  1. Harbor Thermes: From the technique of the masonry we can understand that they were built around the 3rd century BC. They consist of a circular hall with arcades, the walls of which are lined with pierced bricks for heating, while under the vaulted spaces, probably ovens were installed. Later, in the summer of 1936, ruins with mosaics were found west of Thermes.
  2. The northern Thermes: Dated from the 3rd century BC, it is a building with a long hall that was crashed down and fills the floor in several places. It is likely that the northern and western Thermes were built next to a Gymnasium of the Hellenistic era, as evidenced by inscriptions, but the exact position of the Gymnasium has not been verified.
  3. The Stadium: Belongs to the first half of the 2nd century BC, and is located in front of the chapel of St. Anne. It was found that the length of Stadium could not been over 180 meters and the width was about 30 meters. The construction began in 4th-3rd century BC and has Doric and Ionic architectural elements.
  4. "Ksiston" or "Ksistos Dromos (Road)" of the Gymnasium: It belongs to the first half of the 2nd century BC and is located south of the Stadium. In 1938 from the remains of the Gymnasium of Kos, there were found 17 columns made of Kos white marble. It was later found that the length of the school was 180 meters and the width 90 meters and had an open atrium. The architecture of Ksisto of the Western Gymnasium of Kos has all the features that made the city of Kos rivaling with splendor all the capitals of the new kingdoms of the Hellenistic East, since we encounter great detail in the work of the buildings of Kos.
  5.  Western Baths: They are located between the portico of the Gymnasium and the paved road and date from the 3rd century AD. It is a building trapezoidal in shape, with length of 92 meters and width of 35 meters to the north and 33 meters to the south. Later, after the earthquake of 469 AD, a part was turned into an early Christian basilica. On the side, at the northern end of the surface of the excavations there is a room, whose floor is adorned with one of the largest mosaics of Kos.
  6. The paved road (Cardo): The road is dated from the 3rd century AD. It retained almost complete the floor of large slabs made mostly from amygdalopetra and there are still evident the grooves made by the wheels of the vehicles of that era.
  7.  Limestone arcade: It is dated between 4th and 3rd century BC and is located east of the paved road. The destination of the portico is unknown since there were later added walls during the Roman period.
  8. The Forica of the Thermes or Nymphaeum: It was excavated in 1938 and restored in 1940. It is made with cast masonry and belongs in the late 3rd century AD. The decoration was probably consisted of statues and water jets. The floor of the courtyard that had a well at the center, alternates with blocks of marble and mosaics with geometric shapes. The impressive building suffered significant damages in the earthquake of 469 AD.
    9. The road with the arcades (Decumanus): It has width of 10.50 meters, 4,45 of which were the road. The floor plates were made from amygdalopetra, prasinopetra or greenish limestone. The road was one of the arched streets, opened during the imperial period mainly in of Minor Asia and East Africa cities. But the architectural style belongs to the first decades of the 3rd century AD.
    10. The blocks of houses with mosaics and other finds: Traces of reconstruction (following the earthquake of 142 AD) of an earlier Hellenistic house, has a house with a central courtyard and a small toilet. There is interest in the technique of the wall constructions of this house and of the other houses of the district. The house "Mosaic of Europe" took its name from the mosaic of the 3rd AD that adorns the floor of a room. The paintings that adorn these houses are a lot.

Poi.Name: The Sunset of Zia​
Poi.Description:
According to encyclopedic sources, the sunset is determined to be the Sun's disappearance below the Horizon at an azimuth lower greater than three 180 degrees, as a result ​of earth's circumference. However to most of us it certainly does not end there. It is an even capable of sealing one's summer vacation, synonym to being in love for many a poet, scenic in such a manner that compelled every romantic book or movie to place one in its audience's mental eye. Its color so indescribable, its nature so alluring to our senses that many have been caught in dismay within its primal beauty. 

​Why not then, combine such a spectacle with an opulent dinner or a refreshing drink. Zia the islands is the highest settlement upon the island and the perfect spot to observe the luminescent last minutes of sunshine reflected upon the island's crystal blue waters.​​

Poi.Name: Kos Natural park
Poi.Description:
​Find peace and connect with the Nature in Zia Natural Park. Walk on the stone paths between the trees and breath the fresh air. Have a close look at the local animals and plants in their natural environment.

Take a break at the snack bar and enjoy the view while your kids play at the playground. Placed in the best view points, the binoculars offer you a more detailed picture of the island. Tired after a long walk? At the top of the park you will find a special area equipped with hammocks for our guests.

The park is open from 9:00 until 30 minutes after the sunset.

All guests are welcomed to feed the animals in their places or the peacocks that are all over the park.

Poi.Name: Kipriotis Hippocrates
Poi.Description:
Kipriotis Hippocrates is right across the beach in Psalidi, just 3 km from Kos Town. It offers spacious rooms with veranda, as well as 2 pools and a palm-tree garden. 
The modern rooms of Kipriotis Hippocrates are air-conditioned. Each has a fridge, satellite TV and bathroom with hairdryer. From their large verandas guests can enjoy views of the rich greenery. 
The complex offers a restaurant that serves breakfast, lunch and dinner. The 2 bars feature large verandas overlooking the hotel pools. Guests can enjoy a drink or cocktail on the terrace offering a romantic setting. 
Sports and entertainment facilities include 2 tennis courts and table-tennis facilities. There is also an animation program during daytime and in the evening. Two children's pools are provided for younger guests. 
Kos Airport is 25 km away. The lively area of Kardamena is at 30 km. Staff at the 24-hour front desk can arrange car rental.

Poi.Name: Sun Palace Hotel Resort & Spa
Poi.Description:
Sun Palace Hotel Resort & Spa is located 4km from Kos Town and boasts a spa and wellness centre, an outdoor pool, indoor pool, restaurant and free Wi-Fi. Spacious rooms offer a terrace or balcony. 
Modernly decorated, the rooms at Sun Palace are air conditioned. They come with a safe, flat-screen satellite TV, electric kettle and fridge. Bathrobes, slippers and free toiletries stock the stylish bathroom. Each has a garden or Aegean Sea view. 
Guests can dine out on the garden terrace of the on-site buffet restaurant. Cocktails and refreshing drinks are served daily at the bar and at the conveniently located pool bar. 
Sun beds, umbrellas and drink service are provided on the sandy beach. Hotel activities include tennis courts, table tennis, a fitness centre and a playground for the younger guests. 
​Sun Palace Resort Hotel & Spa is 4 km the centre of Kos Town. A variety of restaurants and shops are located within a short walking distance from the hotel. Kos Airport is 26 km away.

Poi.Name: Captain Pavlos Apartments
Poi.Description:
​​Located on the plat North East coast of Kos island, Captain Pavlos resort is an ideal choice for families, couples or young people searching for peaceful and relaxing holidays. Only 80 meters from the beach and 2,5 klm from the north side of Kos town is close to the most interests of the island.
It's first concern is to reach your expectations and for this reason each of the 25 apartments has individual balcony, with sea, pool or country view, bedrooms for 2 persons (special arrangement for a 5 person family), fully equipped kitchenette and strict cleaning service while the swimming pool, the small restaurant with a wide pavilion, the mini market, TV lounge, telephone service, safe boxes, offer a cool and safe environment.
Especially for children we make a small swimming pool, play room and a grass playground for endless entertainment. All these are surrounded by blooming flowers and palm trees, so thinking of them all together you can imagine you're in a small paradise.
Still if you want to get out of this paradise there is a local bus service at the front of the apartments or even bicycles and motorbikes to hire. The most important for them is to make you feel like home, that's why they stay with you in the complex to offer any assistance to you in small or serious problems day and night. You can be sure that all the people in Captain Pavlos will try hard for that, so they welcome you to be a part of the family.​​

Poi.Name: Mikri Poli
Poi.Description:
Mikri Poli is located on Kardamena’s beachfront, 9 km from the Kos’ airport. The 5-star resort features a 1,000-m² freshwater pool and 2 shallow pools for children. The sandy-pebble beach is 50 metres from the hotel.

Guest rooms’ features include a 20-inch flat-screen satellite TV, 2 phones, individual climate control, mini refrigerator and tea-and-coffee-making facilities. Spacious and bright, they have sea or garden views.

Set on an impressive veranda, the resort’s main restaurant serves local and international delicacies, and features live pasta and grill stations, healthy choices and children’s menus. The Pool House is open all day for late breakfast, snacks and pastries.

Sports facilities include a multi court for tennis, basketball and mini football, aerobics classes, water sports and a fitness room. There are also 2 open-air theatres, mini club, as well as a play station corner and an internet corner available on site.

The hotel is a convenient 10-minute walk to town. Mikri Poli is approximately 30 km away from Kos Town and port. Free private parking is available on site.

Poi.Name: Stella Maris
Poi.Description:
​The combination of local traditional architecture and up to date facilities, for your comfort and pleasure, creates a warm, friendly and relaxing atmosphere. They strive to provide excellent service to all the guests, of all ages.

The three star hotel consists of four individual buildings and the reception building and has in total 98 rooms. It provides comfortable rooms and studios aesthetically pleasing in their simplicity, offering a breathtaking view over the sea, ready to accommodate couples, friends and families for unforgettable holidays. Each room is equipped with a shower or bath, WC, telephone, TV, air condition, refrigerator, safety deposit box and balcony or terrace with beautiful sea, or garden-pool view.

Poi.Name: Double Tree Resort by Hilton - Helona
Poi.Description:
​​Overlooking the clear blue waters of the Aegean Sea, the DoubleTree by Hilton Resort Kos - Helona is the perfect beach retreat. Enjoy equal parts adventure and luxury just off the southern coast of Kos, a beautiful island of the Greek Dodecanese Group. Experience colorful nightlife, sandy beaches and various cultural attractions when staying at this Kos hotel.

Guest rooms feature beautiful views of the sea or garden, a custom-designed bed, and high-speed internet access. Upgrade to a luxury suite or villa to enjoy a private pool. Host an unforgettable event in three event spaces with a total capacity for 700 guests. Stay connected in the business center, offering full support services and WiFi in public areas.

Poi.Name: Astir Odysseus
Poi.Description: Astir Odysseus is located in Kos, a wonderful Greek island where, in addition to beautiful nature sites, you will admire the coves, beaches, crystal-clear waters and waves that gently caress the local shores.

Poi.Name: Andreas Studios
Poi.Description:
Andreas Studios is a family-run hotel located in the village Mastichari, and is a 5-minute walk from the beach. It offers air-conditioned rooms with free Wi-Fi, and fully-equipped kitchenettes.

Rooms at the Studios are bright, and feature furnished balconies with panoramic views. They come equipped with a safety deposit box, and cable TV. The kitchens include a refrigerator and a hot plate.

The Mastichari Ferry Terminal is less than a 5-minute walk from the Andreas Studios. The Ippokratis Airport is situated less than 7 km from the hotel.

Andreas provides private taxi transportation to the airport on request. Free public parking is possible at a location nearby.

Poi.Name: PORTO BELLO ROYAL
Poi.Description:
The perfect place for a vacation where the modern architecture is combined in local harmony with the natural environment. Situated on the Southern coast of Kos, the Porto Bello Royal is a cosmopolitan 5 star ultra all inclusive resort, 3 Km away from the village of Kardamena and 9 Km from Kos Hippocrates International airport.
The Hotel is made in a superb Mediterranean design, with one storey mansions and bungalows, with a total of 310 Luxury rooms and Suites. The service is second to none, the location is perfect. Surrounded by water gardens with a magnificent view of the Mediterranean Sea and the volcanic island of Nissyros, its ambience is delightfully tranquil. Just a stone's throw from the private beach, a gorgeous gold-dust slice of sands that melts into sapphire-blue seas. Fifteen pools to choose from, including an outdoor children’s pool and elegant indoor pool. A rare place where sophistication and fun co-exist in perfect harmony.

Poi.Name: Fenareti Hotel
Poi.Description:
A nice, simple, clean and quiet hotel in the village of Mastihari. A few reasons to stay  here during your summer holiday are the followings:
  • Rooms are cleaned every day (except Sundays).
  • Bed linen and towels are changed twice a week.
  • Rooms are more like little apartments with kitchen and private bathroom.
  • Plenty parking space for your (rental) car or bike.
  • Location which is  maximum of 5 minutes walk to the mini-market, car and bike rental, harbour, bars and restaurants, beach, surf&sail centre, bus stop and swimming pools.
  • Convinient prices.
  • Speaking languages :Greek, English, German and Dutch!

Poi.Name: Blue Lagoon Resort
Poi.Description:
The Blue Lagoon Resort offers 5-star accommodation just 2 km from Kos town and 75 metres from the beach. It includes a luxurious 4,000-m² pool, a spa and a mini-golf course.

Blue Lagoon’s rooms offer balconies that overlook the sea or the gardens. All are air-conditioned and feature a satellite TV, a coffee maker and a mini fridge.

Dining options include Greek and Italian cuisine, a BBQ and grill restaurant, and a crepes/sandwiches snack bar. Among the 10 bars featured, 3 bars are poolside.

The Apivita & Votsalo Spa uses the finest APIVITA Greek aromatherapy products. It features an indoor pool, hot tub, fitness room, 2 saunas and a steam bath.

Ancient Agora, the Tree of Hippocrates and the monastery of Agia Paraskevi are all less than 20 minutes’ walk away.

Poi.Name: Sonia Hotel
Poi.Description:
Quietly situated in the town of Kos, family-run Hotel Sonia is just 100 metres from the beach and just 50 metres from restaurants and shops. It features rooms with free Wi-Fi and views of the sea and the ancient Roman ruins.

Air conditioning, an LCD satellite TV and fridge are included in all accommodation at the Sonia Hotel. A private bathroom with shower and hairdryer is provided. All rooms have a furnished balcony.

A homemade breakfast is served in the terrace. Drinks and coffee are provided at the bar.

The multilingual staff at the 24-hour front desk can arrange for the rental of a car, bicycle or moped. The scenic Thermes Beach is 12 km away. Kos International Airport is at 25 km.

Poi.Name: Carda Beach Hotel - Adults Only
Poi.Description:
Each stylish room at the Carda Beach offers comfortable beds, a DVD player and a luxurious bathroom with hairdryer. All rooms have private balconies with views of the sea or the garden.

Mediteranneo Restaurant is located right on the pool’s edge. It serves American breakfast, lunch and dinner buffet inspired by Greek and International cuisine. The Asian Wok n' roll restaurant offers eastern flavours along with views of the swimming pool.

Carda Spa provides a full range of revitalising services, including saunas, hamams (Turkish bath), hot tub and a tranquil relaxation lounge with heated armchairs.

​

Poi.Name: Hotel Christina
Poi.Description: ​Hotel Kardamena.

Poi.Name: Olympia Mare
Poi.Description:
​Welcome to Olympia Mare Beach Hotel. Enjoy the Greek hospitality.
A friendly and small family complex, with Aegean Style environment.
Olympia Mare Beach Hotel is located just outside Kardamena (1.6km) on a quiet stretch of beach, 7km from airport and 27km from Kos town.
It is a friendly and small family complex, with Aegean Style environment, ideal for families with children and couples.

Poi.Name: Diamond Deluxe Hotel
Poi.Description:
Diamond Deluxe Hotel rooms are luxuriously decorated in shades of white with golden details and hardwood floors. They are equipped with air conditioning, LCD satellite TV and DVD player, and feature hydromassage facilities. Their balconies or verandas boast spectacular views of the sea or the pools.

The Mazarin Spa includes 5 state-of-the-art treatment rooms and an indoor pool with water jets. Natural ingredients are used in all therapies following the holistic philosophy of the spa.

Emerald Restaurant serves a rich breakfast buffet overlooking the pools and the gardens, while the Peruzzi Italian Restaurant offers local seafood with a modern twist. Hotel Diamond Deluxe also has three bars, at the lobby, the pool and the beach, serving drinks and exotic cocktails in elegant settings.

Diamond Deluxe Hotel is within 3 km from the town of Kos. The airport is 24 km away. Free private parking is available on site.

​

Poi.Name: Aquis Marine Resort & Waterpark
Poi.Description:
On holidays with children? Look no further! Aquis Marine Resort and Waterpark is your paradise. What if mum likes reading, dad loves relaxing by the pool and the children prefer the kids club or the water slides? No need to worry about conflicts or sacrifices, you have found the perfect holiday destination.

The Aquis Marine Resort & Waterpark offers:

 

  • 298 family rooms, of which 198 one bedroom family rooms and 100 two bedroom family rooms each with a private balcony
  • Exceptional waterpark facilities
  • Child friendly
  • Activities for every family member
  • Free WI-FI throughout all hotel areas

 

Hotel Location
Located near the beach of Tigaki, North part of Kos

 

Special Notice
Suitable for disabled guests

 

Special Highlights

  • Children's paradise
  • Waterpark destination resort
  • Animation programme including sports day & evening entertainment
  • Social atmosphere

Poi.Name: Koni Doris
Poi.Description: ​Hotel in Kos.

Poi.Name: Akti Dimis Hotel
Poi.Description:
Akti Dimis is situated directly across the road from Tigaki’s sandy beach and 500 metres from the resort centre. It offers self catering studios, a snack bar/restaurant and an all-day pool.

Ideal for a relaxing holiday on the Greek island of Kos, the family run Akti Dimmis Hotel has an inviting swimming pool and sun terrace furnished with loungers, a snack bar/restaurant, a pool table and games room, an internet corner and a bar with satellite television.

The studios have air conditioning, a kitchenette with fridge, bathroom and balcony or terrace whilst the apartments are more spacious with an additional bedroom.

Tigaki lies about 10 miles from the airport that has seen a lot of expansion in recent years. The long and sandy beach is one of the best on the island, offering a host of water sports.

Poi.Name: Neptune Hotel
Poi.Description: ​Neptune Hotels - Resort, Convention Centre & Spa, an ample holiday resort on the island of Kos with rooms, suites and apartments is built in the traditional style of the Greek island architecture and located directly at a long sandy beach. The complex offers luxurious facilities and first-class accommodation in its main building as well as in the surrounding bungalow units, complimented by the traditional Greek hospitality. Four restaurants, seven bars, four outdoor pools, a modern conference centre, various sports facilities, professional child care, diversified evening entertainment as well as the relaxing ambience of the Neptune Spa reflect the high level of comfort and service at Neptune Hotels.​

Poi.Name: Angela Tingaki
Poi.Description: ​Hotel in Tigkaki.

Poi.Name: Aqua Blu Boutique Hotel and Spa
Poi.Description: Aqua Blu, a proud member of the Small Luxury Hotels of the World, is the ultimate destination for luxury and contemporary design. A unique 5 star boutique hotel with a state of the art spa, set on a beautiful waterfront...  The Aqua Blu Boutique Hotel + Spa is located at Lambi Beach, one of the most attractive beaches on Kos Island. Lambi Beach stretches out of the harbor to the northern tip and around the headland of the Island. ​

Poi.Name: Achileas Beach
Poi.Description:
EUROVILLAGE ACHILLEAS Hotel is situated in the area of Mastichari, on the Northwest side of the island of Kos.
Built upon a wonderful stretch of beach, it's a modern hotel complex with all its rooms scattered around the green gardens. The airport and the village of Antimachia are about 6km away and Kos Town is about 22km. (hotel shuttle bus to Kos town is available several times per week). Mastichari itself is a beachside village with about 700 inhabitants. It can be visited from our hotel just by taking a short stroll along the beachfront.​

Poi.Name: Aramni
Poi.Description:
​Apartments ARAMNI are located at Tigaki on Kos island.
8km from Kos town,15km from airport,700m from the center of Tigaki,150m from bus station and mini-market,restaurant.
Spacious apartments with private balcony facing the sea or mountain Dikaios.All are equiped with air condition,kitchen,refrigerator,tv,internet access.
Perfect for relaxing vacations and swimming!

Poi.Name: Ariadni Hotel
Poi.Description: Hotel in Tigkaki.

Poi.Name: Aspro Spiti
Poi.Description:
​ASPRO SPITI is a traditional hotel offering alternative tourism. Owned by Diakanastasis family, it is located in Tigaki Kos, since 1984. 
The visitor who would choose ASPRO SPITI as their holiday destination shall have the unique opportunity of experiencing Greek culture, civilization and hospitality.  
The visitor of Aspro Spiti, has the opportunity to try traditional homemade dishes made with fresh local ingredients prepared by dietician and to choose one of our athletic programs with professional trainers
Aspro Spiti, offers free parking and Wi-Fi

Poi.Name: Golden Sun Apartments
Poi.Description:
​Golden Sun Apartments is a small but spacious complex, ideal for couples and families.

Go there and enjoy it's friendly atmosphere.

Poi.Name: Michelangelo
Poi.Description:
Rising above the pebble beach of Agios Fokas, this ultramodern 5-star hotel has 2 impressive infinity pools, panoramic decked terraces and spa facilities. Rooms have furnished sea-view porches.

All rooms at the Michelangelo Resort & Spa are styled in soothing, modern colors. Most include a sitting area. Cable TV, minibar and air conditioning are standard.

The spa features Turkish baths, sauna and hot tub. You can also indulge yourself with one of the great massage treatments offered. Guests can enjoy the sunset from one of the hotel's 3 outdoor swimming pools.

A varied breakfast buffet is served at the elegant restaurant, overlooking the sea and the pool. Options from the menu are available for lunch and dinner. There is also a pool bar, and a piano bar.

Agios Fokas with its peble beach and small number of taverns is within easy walking distance, and Kos Town is 5 miles away reached easily by a 10-minute bus ride.

Poi.Name: Ipanema Hotel
Poi.Description: ​Hotel in Tigkaki.

Poi.Name: Kalloudis Apartments
Poi.Description: ​Situated in the quiet resort of Tigaki, these apartments are within close walking distance of the beach, shops, bars and restaurants. Family run and traditional, the Kalloudis offers modern and comfortable accommodation, for a peaceful and relaxing holiday.

Poi.Name: Sun Garden Village
Poi.Description: ​Hotel in Kos.

Poi.Name: Katras Apartments
Poi.Description:
With a state-of-the-art architectural style, just a few metres from the sandy beach of Tingaki, a small village on Kos Island, these apartments were built in 2003.

The apartments are bright and spacious (40 m²) and there is a fast food restaurant on-site. You can also enjoy Spiros, our traditional family tavern, and there is a supermarket with a wide selection of goods at reasonable prices just a few metres from the hotel.

You will be excited by the artistic style and design of our bar, which operates both indoors and outdoors. You can enjoy all sorts of drinks, cocktails and beverages, while watching our widescreen TV, or playing billiards. The bar also has 2 pool tables, electronic darts and table football at an additional cost. The TV has satellite channels available.

Poi.Name: Palazzo Del Mare
Poi.Description: Among its most notable amenities is the hotel’s prime location near the Castle Palaio Pyli and Asklepion. Come and go as you please via a 24-hour front desk, enjoying the unique culture and beauty of the Greek Isles. ​

Poi.Name: Marianna Hotel Apartments
Poi.Description: ​Kos hotel "Marianna" is located 750 meters from the amazing beach of Tigaki and just 200 meters from the center of the area where restaurants, cafeterias and several markets are found. It disposes 53 self catering studios and apartments, fully renovated in 2011, isolated enough from the noisy center and surrounded by nature, palm trees, olive trees and colorful roses.

Poi.Name: Sovereign
Poi.Description: ​A friendly, modern and well run hotel, it is surrounded by attractive and well kept gardens with good sports facilities and a fun programme of day and evening entertainment. Suitable for both families and couples alike, the hotel provides an ideal holiday base for a relaxing and enjoyable stay. ​

Poi.Name: Marmari Palace
Poi.Description: ​The club is on the beach, 18km from Kos city.

Poi.Name: Norida Beach
Poi.Description: ​All room types include the comforts and amenities guests can expect from a luxury 5-star hotel. They are individually designed in a contemporary style with personal touches and quietly overlook the hotel's landscaped gardens or the sea. Guests will forget very soon that they are in a hotel and feel thoroughly at home!

Poi.Name: Mythos Apartments
Poi.Description: ​Mythos Apartments are centrally located in the resort of Tigaki, this friendly and relaxing accommodation is a popular choice with families and couples alike. It is situated only 100m from the sandy Tigaki Beach. There is a small swimming pool and terrace with sunloungers and parasols.

Poi.Name: Kos Imperial Grecotel
Poi.Description:
Boasting a private beach, and 6 landscaped pools with waterfalls and rivers, Kos Imperial features 5-star accommodation set within exotic gardens, in Psalidi area. It offers a spa centre and a variety of gourmet dining options. ​

Guests can enjoy massage and beauty therapies at the hotel’s spa. State-of-the-art facilities also include an indoor pool, jacuzzi and steam rooms. 2 tennis courts and a water sports school are available.

Grecotel guests can choose among Mediterranean cuisine, fresh seafood and traditional Greek tastes. The main bar and the beach bar serve drinks and cocktails in colonial lounges and sea-view terraces.

Kos Airport is 35 km away from the resort, while the port is at just 4 km. Kos Imperial provides Wi-Fi access and free parking is available on site.

Poi.Name: Lakithira
Poi.Description:
With excellent water sports facilities and an award-winning tennis centre, Lakitira Resort is set in four acres of flower-filled gardens with 2 beach areas and 2 large swimming pools. The 4-star resort is located along the coast of Kardamena.

Spread amongst colourful gardens, Lakitira air-conditioned rooms have flat screen TVs, safes, fridges and tea-and-coffee making facilities. Many enjoy views of the sea from their balconies.

Poi.Name: Family Village
Poi.Description:
The all-inclusive 4-star Mitsis Family Village is just 200 metres from the pebbled beach of Kardamena. Umbrellas and loungers are offered both by the 2 outdoor pools and on the beach.

Rooms are elegantly appointed in Mediterranean colours, and offer views to the mountain and the sea. Each is air conditioned and has private bathroom with hairdryer. Some rooms include a kitchenette.

Poi.Name: Sunny Days Hotel
Poi.Description:
Surrounded by a well-tended garden, 900 metres from Tigaki Beach of Kos, Sunny Days features self-catering accommodation with a private balcony. The property’s public areas include a pool, a restaurant and a bar and offer free Wi-Fi.

A kitchenette with a cooking hobs, fridge and electric kettle is available in the spacious units of Sunny Days. Each accommodation includes a private bathroom stocked with a hairdryer.

A buffet breakfast is offered daily, while guests can also taste Greek flavours at the on-site restaurant. Beverages, cocktails and snacks are served at the bar. Guests can find a big supermarket within 50 metres of the property.

Leisure facilities include a games room, billiards and a children’s playground. The multilingual staff at the front desk can arrange car and bicycle rental and can provide information on excursions to the area.

Sunny Days is located 12 km from the capital of Kos and 20 km from Kos Airport Hippocrates. Pyli village is at 6 km and Zipari is at 2 km. Free private parking is available on site.

Poi.Name: Summer Palace Hotel
Poi.Description: The Summer Palace consists of 172 Rooms in the main Building and in Bungalows, 80 Family Suites of two Rooms with sharing pools - 10 Suites for each pool.​

Poi.Name: Tropical Sol
Poi.Description:
Tropical Sol is located only 200 metres from the sea in Tigaki, one of the most popular destinations of the island of Kos, approximately 10 kilometres from the Town of Kos.

All rooms are supplied with air-conditioning, heating, satellite TV, refrigerator and balcony with view to the garden and the sea.

Tropical Sol houses a cafe bar with garden view, a snack bar, swimming pool, playground, and ping-pong facilities.

Tigaki’s long sandy beach has been awarded with the blue flag for its cleanliness and its excellent facilities.

Poi.Name: Villa Andrews Hotel
Poi.Description: ​Villa Andrews is a family run hotel with 27 rooms, each room catering for two or three people , all en suite with a balcony. There are also 9 triple sized bungalows and an extra large family sized bungalow. All are surrounded by luscious beautiful gardens bursting with greenery. All our rooms and bungalows are well maintained to ensure your stay is a pleasant one. Villa Andrews is ideal for families and those looking for a little relaxation. Villa Andrews is located in Tigaki about 11km from Kos Town. Tigaki is ideally situated as it allows the visitor to spend a quiet holiday, but is a quick bus or taxi ride away from Kos Town. There is a regular bus service to Kos Town and taxis are available on request.

Poi.Name: Arant Hotel
